### Get the Reddit app
Scan this QR code to download the app now
Or check it out in the app stores
An Unethical Life Pro Tip (or ULPT) is a tip that improves your life in a meaningful way, perhaps at the expense of others and/or with questionable legality. Due to their nature, do not actually follow any of these tips–they're just for fun. Share your best tips you've picked up throughout your life, and learn from others!
* * *
Members Online
•
ADMIN MOD
ULPT request: Hobby Lobby doesn't use barcodes, can you swap a tag from a similar cheaper product to a more expensive one to get a discount?
============================================================================================================================================
I really want this model that's in stock at my local Hobby Lobby, but it costs $80, and I don't have $80 dispensable at the moment. The price tags are stickers that can easily be peeled off then stuck to something else. Could one theoretically grab a tag off of one of the other models that's like $18 and put it on the $80 one and get away with it? The models are robots from an anime that all have names like SY-89-3 (😉), so even if the serial number on the tag they punch in brings up the product name on the computer I doubt they'd notice. Thoughts?
Read more

Breadcrumb navigation links:  |  |  |  | Current page: Answer
Answer
======
Returns - In-Store Purchases
----------------------------
**With the original receipt**
Within 90 days of purchase, we will gladly exchange the merchandise, give store credit, or issue a refund based on your original method of payment. There will be a wait of 10 calendar days on check purchases, or merchandise credit can be issued.
**Without the original store receipt**
You may exchange the merchandise or be issued a merchandise credit based on the lowest selling price in the last 60 days. A valid ID is required. We reserve the right to limit or refuse to accept the return of certain products and non-receipted items.
**Prohibited Returns**
Please view a list of prohibited returns .

Hobby Lobby 101: explaining the Supreme Court's birth control ruling
====================================================================
The Hobby Lobby case decided by the Supreme Court last month sent ripples through the national conversation on women's rights and religion in public life. Here, we explain the basics of what the Supreme Court did.
    !
|
Hobby Lobby/AP
The Green family, who are evangelical Christians, own the Hobby Lobby, which has more than 15,000 full-time employees in more than 600 crafts stores in 41 states. The Supreme Court ruled on June 30 that the chain does not have to provide all forms of birth control to female employees.
Loading...
*   By  Staff writer
July 10, 2014
The  ruled on June 30 that the owners of closely-held, profit-making corporations cannot be forced under the  to provide their employees with certain kinds of contraceptives that offend their religious beliefs.
The decision arose from litigation filed by the owners of the national chain of craft stores called Hobby Lobby, and the owners of Conestoga Wood Specialties, a cabinetmaker in Pennsylvania.
It has sparked a heated debate about the scope of religious liberty in the United States and whether bosses are now empowered to impose their religious beliefs on their employees. It has also raised concerns that female workers will now be denied access to contraceptives.
#### What was the basis of the owners’ religious objections?
Both Hobby Lobby and Conestoga Wood are controlled by family members with shared religious beliefs. Those beliefs hold that life begins at conception and that any birth control method that may result in the destruction of a fertilized egg is a form of abortion and killing that is forbidden by their faith.
They also believe that supporting and financing their company health care plan in a way that provides their employees with the means to destroy a fertilized egg makes them complicit in a sinful and immoral act.
#### Do they oppose all birth control?
No. Their objections were to four of 18 methods required to be provided to...[Content truncated]

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... white molding that was always out of stock. Reason being… our basic was 2, I’d order 2 every week, they’d sell out every week… one week our DM decided to stop in to do a stock test, and low and behold, that frame is on his test, and I failed for missing that item… I check my shipping list since I knew I ordered it, it’s on it, and there is two somewhere in the store, and they should be either on the shelf or in my frame shop if the glass broke on the truck so I can fix it. I check our back room, and in a box is my two frames, one with the glass shattered, one completely undamaged. Next thing you know; I pass my stock test, store manager gets in trouble because that box should’ve been delivered to me two days ago, since once I finish unloading that truck on Monday, it’s home decors responsibility to get any frames mixed in with home decor to me by the end of the day.
Upvote ·
94
Related questions
More answers below
]
Outside Sales Representative of building materials · Author has 3.9K answers and 7M answer views
 · 
I owned a retail store from 1989 to 1994. While there were barcodes on most, if not all, of the packaged products I sold, scanning wasn’t nearly as common back then. I owned a store that sold carpenter tools. A lot of the items that I sold were loose, like drillbits, driver bits and nuts and bolts.
So, I had item codes. They followed a pretty simple protocol. If a power tool was from Porter Cable, the code was PC and then the model number. So the 7/8 horse power, ¼” router was PC 100.
A 1/8” carbon steel drillbit was 18CSDB. A Stanley 25’ tape measure was ST33425. 25 years later and I remember m
Continue Reading
